## Instructions simplified

1.  In **CLI** [(e.g. RStudio Terminal, PowerShell, Bash, etc.)]{style="color: gray; font-size: large;"}:<br/>`quarto create` \> `project` \> `manuscript`
    -   [Identify LFS path / location]{style="color: gray;"}
2.  Go to that location; double-click \<new_proj_name\>.Rproj file [(if using R)]{style="color: gray; font-size: large;"}
3.  `useths::use_git()`
4.  in `_quarto.yml`: change `jats: default` to `pdf: default`

## Binder (Containers)

\

The Binder project makes it easy to share compute environments. This is [documented](https://quarto.org/docs/projects/binder.html) very well at Quarto.

In essence:

-   CLI terminal: `quarto use binder`

::: aside
Recommended: While [sharing your compute environments](https://quarto.org/docs/projects/binder.html) consider sharing your GitHub [Releases](https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-github/about-releases) while simultaneously minting DOIs. This [makes your content citable](https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/archiving-a-github-repository/referencing-and-citing-content) and places your milestones into the [Zenodo](https://about.zenodo.org/) archive for posterity.
:::
